docs.lead_paragraph: Marco Antonio Barrera comes from a privileged background by Mexican standards. His father is a backdrop designer for television, and Barrera dropped out of law school at the University of Mexico in his hometown of Mexico City to concentrate on his boxing career nine years ago. Growing up, Barrera chose boxing over soccer, to the dismay of his parents. Erik Morales comes from an impoverished background by most standards, but he was born to a life of boxing. His mother gave birth to him on the first floor of a building that housed a boxing gym in Tijuana, Mexico. Morales is trained by his father, Jose Morales Damian, a former flyweight contender, who wanted his son to attend the university.
docs.abstract: Marco Antonio Barrera and Erik Morales, two Mexican 122-pound world boxing champions with disparate backgrounds, will meet in Las Vegas in long anticipated bout, to be broadcast on HBO (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A Story Twice Told With one production of ''The Wild Party'' under way and the second beginning to strut its stuff, speculation was rife this week that both shows might soon be playing on Broadway simultaneously. If everything fell into place, this could set up the tantalizing possibility that two shows with the same name and source material would vie for best musical at the Tony Awards. The source is Joseph Moncure March's poem ''The Wild Party'' (1928), which tells the story of jazz-era bohemians on the prowl during a debauched soiree.

docs.snippet: 'Cider House' A Dark Horse?      Well, Miramax is doing it again. Can no one stop this?    The little-independent-that-could, now an independent-minded cog in the Disney empire, has dominated the Academy Awards for a half-dozen years or so, with b...
docs.lead_paragraph: 'Cider House' A Dark Horse? Well, Miramax is doing it again. Can no one stop this? The little-independent-that-could, now an independent-minded cog in the Disney empire, has dominated the Academy Awards for a half-dozen years or so, with best-picture Oscars in 1997 for ''The English Patient'' and in 1999 for ''Shakespeare in Love.'' In this year's tight race, with no film dominating the proceedings and no clear favorite in any major category, it was always assumed that one or two dark horses could emerge in the nominations, announced on Tuesday. But very few expected that Miramax's ''Cider House Rules'' would not only get a best-picture nomination but would also be tied for second (with Michael Mann's ''Insider'') in total nominations, seven. ''Cider House,'' playing on only about 800 screens at the moment and just beginning its wide theatrical run, now stands to capitalize on the momentum of the nominations and could suddenly become a serious contender for best picture as well (although the top nomination-getter, ''American Beauty,'' with eight, remains the narrow betting favorite in Hollywood).

docs.lead_paragraph: Charlie Gordon is a tough role for any actor. Oscar voters recognized that and gave Cliff Robertson the best actor award for the 1968 film ''Charly.'' (Spelling consistency has never been the entertainment industry's strong suit.) Now Matthew Modine takes on the challenge in a CBS movie, ''Flowers for Algernon'' (the title of the Daniel Keyes novel on which both films are based), and while he does an admirable job, the resulting film makes Mr. Robertson's achievement seem all the more astonishing in comparison.

docs.snippet: ''American Beauty,'' a vinegary comedy about suburbanites whose lives are so askew that they seem to have turned dysfunction into an art form, came away with the most Academy Awards nominations today, but it was a close call. Share the wealth seem...
docs.lead_paragraph: ''American Beauty,'' a vinegary comedy about suburbanites whose lives are so askew that they seem to have turned dysfunction into an art form, came away with the most Academy Awards nominations today, but it was a close call. Share the wealth seemed to be the theme of the day. ''American Beauty'' drew eight nominations, including best picture, best actor (Kevin Spacey), best actress (Annette Bening) and best director (the British stage veteran Sam Mendes in his movie debut). But right behind, with seven nominations each, were ''The Insider'' (including best picture, Russell Crowe for best actor and Michael Mann for best director) and, in something of a surprise, ''The Cider House Rules'' (including best picture, Lasse Hallstrom for best director and Michael Caine for best supporting actor). And right behind them was the surprise hit ''The Sixth Sense,'' with six nominations (including best picture, and both writing and directing by M. Night Shyamalan).

Case in point: the Red Ball on Monday night, the annual charity fund-raising event given by the producer MARTIN RICHARDS in honor of his wife, MARY LEA JOHNSON RICHARDS. As it happened, GEORGETTE MOSBACHER, the author and businesswoman, was the last in a long string of speakers in the grand ballroom of the Plaza Hotel. At last, Ms. Mosbacher, her flaming red hair set off by her red-lace gown, took the podium to read a laudatory letter about the event from MAYOR RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI.
